entry.title: Topological Properties
entry.content:
1. The Countability Axioms

Definition 1.1   A topological space is said to be first-countable if each point has a countable neighbourhood basis.

A neighborhood basis of $x\in X$ is a collection $\mathcal{B}$ of neighborhoods of $x$ such that each neighborhood of $x$ contains at least one of the elements of $\mathcal{B}$. In fact, if $x$ has a countable neighborhood basis $\{U_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$, there must be a nonincreasing sequence $V_1\supset V_2\supset V_3\supset\dots$, such that $\{V_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ is also a countable neighborhood basis of $x$, since we can simply let $V_i= igcap_{j=1}^i U_j$.

Proposition 1.1   If $X$ is a first-countable space, $A$ is a subset of $X$, then:

  • $x\in ar{A} \iff$ there exists a sequence of $A$ converges to $x$.
  • $x\in\mathring{A} \iff$ only finite terms of each sequence of $X$ converges to $x$ are belonging to $A^\mathsf{c}$.

Proof.  

  • $(\Leftarrow)$.   If the sequence $\{x_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ of $A$ converges to $x$, then each neighborhood of $x$ intersects $A$ with some terms of $\{x_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ which means $x\in ar{A}$.
    $(\Rightarrow)$.   Consider a nonincreasing countable neighborhood basis $\mathcal{B}=\{B_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ of $x$, we can find $x_i\in A$ for each $B_i\in\mathcal{B}$ such that $x_i\in B_i$ since $x\in ar{A}$. From the definition, for each neighborhood $U$ of $x$, $\exists B_N\subset U$, then, for all integers $i>N$, we have $x_i\in B_i\subset B_N\subset U$, thus $\{x_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ converges to $x$.
  • $(\Rightarrow)$.   Directly holds by the definition of convergence since $\mathring{A}$ is a neighborhood of $x$.
    $(\Leftarrow)$.   We assume that $x ot\in\mathring{A}$, then $x\in (\mathring{A})^\mathsf{c}= \overline{A^\mathsf{c}}$, from the previous conclusion, there exists a sequence $\{x_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ of $A^\mathsf{c}$ converges to $x$, which is a contradiction. $\square$

Examples 1.1   The metric spaces are first-countable.

Since $\{B(x, rac{1}{n})\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ is a countable neighborhood basis of $x$.

Examples 1.2   The Sorgenfrey line $\mathbb{R}_l$ is first-countable.

Since $\{[x,x+q)\}_{q\in\mathbb{Q}}$ is a countable neighborhood basis of $x$.

Examples 1.3   $\mathbb{R}$ with cocountable topology $\mathcal{T}_c$ is not first-countable.

In fact, if it is, the point $x\in\mathbb{R}$ has a countable neighborhood basis $\{U_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$, since $( igcap_{i=1}^\infty U_i)^{\mathsf{c}}= igcup_{i=1}^\infty U_i^{\mathsf{c}}$ which is a countable set, then $ igcap_{i=1}^\infty U_i\in\mathcal{T}_c$ and consists of infinitely many elements since $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable, therefore, we choose $y\in igcap_{i=1}^\infty U_i$ such that $y eq x$, then $( igcup_{i=1}^\infty U_i)\setminus\{y\}\in\mathcal{T}_c$ and contains no elements of $\{U_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$, which is a contradiction.

Definition 1.2   A topological space is said to be second-countable if there is a countable basis for its topology.

Definition 1.3   A topological space is said to be separable if it contains a countable, dense subset.

Definition 1.4   A topological space is said to be Lindelöf if every open covering for it contains a countable subcovering.

Proposition 1.2   If $X$ is a second-countable space, then:

  • $X$ is a first-countable space.
  • $X$ is a separable space.
  • $X$ is a Lindelöf space.

Proof.  

  • Let $\mathcal{B}$ be a countable basis of $X$, then for each point $x\in X$, $\{B\in\mathcal{B}\colon\ x\in B\}$ is a countable neighborhood basis of $x$ since each neighborhood of $x$ is an union of elements of $\mathcal{B}$.
  • Let $\mathcal{B}=\{B_i\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ be a countable basis of $X$, $A=\{x_i\in X\colon\ i\in\mathbb{N}, x_i\in B_i\}$ which is a countable set. $ orall x\in X$, each neighborhood $U$ of $x$ contains at least one element $B_N\in\mathcal{B}$, then $x_N\in B_N\subset U \implies U\cap A eq\varnothing$, therefor $ ar{A}=X$, $X$ is separable.
  • Let $\mathcal{B}$ be a countable basis of $X$, $\mathcal{U}$ is an open covering of $X$. We then let $\mathcal{B}’=\{B\in\mathcal{B}\colon\ \exists U\in\mathcal{U}, \mathcal{B}\subset U\}$ and $\mathcal{U}’=\{U_i\in\mathcal{U}\colon\ B_i\in\mathcal{B}, U_i\supset B_i\}$ which are countable. Since $\mathcal{U}$ is an open covering of $X$, for each $x\in X$ there must be a neighborhood $U_x\in\mathcal{U}$ of $x$ and a basis element $B_x$ such that $B_x\subset U_x$, which means $B_x\in\mathcal{B}’$ and therefore $U_x\in\mathcal{U}’$, so $\mathcal{U}’$ is a countable subcovering of $\mathcal{U}$ of $X$, $X$ is Lindelöf. $\square$

Proposition 1.3   If $X$ is a metric space, then:

$X$ is separable $\iff$ $X$ is second-countable $\iff$ $X$ is Lindelöf.

Proof.   It suffices to show that both separability and Lindelöf property imply second-countability, in the metric spaces.

  • If $X$ is separable, there exists a countable subset $A$ such that $ ar{A}=X$. Let $\mathcal{B}=\{B(x,q)\colon\ x\in A, q\in\mathbb{Q}^+\}$, we then prove that $\mathcal{B}$ is a countable basis of $X$.
    For each $x\in X$, each neighborhoods $U$ of $x$ contains a $\delta$-ball: $B(x,\delta)$, since $ ar{A}=X$, there is a point $y\in A$ such that $y\in B(x, rac{\delta}{3})$, we choose a positive rational number $q$ such that $ rac{\delta}{3}<q< rac{2\delta}{3}$, then $x\in B(y,q)\subset B(x,\delta)\subset U$, since $ orall z\in B(y,q)$, $B(x,z)\leq B(x,y)+B(y,z)< rac{\delta}{3}+ rac{2\delta}{3}=\delta$. Therefore, $\mathcal{B}$ is a countable basis of $X$.
  • If $X$ is Lindelöf, let $\mathcal{U}_n=\{B(x, rac{1}{n})\colon\ x\in X\}$ be a collection of open covering of $X$, then we have countable subcovring $\mathcal{V}_n=\{B(x_i^{(n)}, rac{1}{n})\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}$ for each $\mathcal{U}_n$. We then prove that $\mathcal{V}=\{B(x_i^{(n)}, rac{1}{n})\colon\ i,n\in\mathbb{N}\}$ is a countable basis of $X$.
    For each $x\in X$, each neighborhoods $U$ of $x$ contains a $\delta$-ball: $B(x,\delta)$. Let $n$ suffitiently large such that $ rac{1}{n}<\delta$, since $\mathcal{V}_{2n}$ is a covering, there exists a point $y$ such that $x\in B(y, rac{1}{2n})\in \mathcal{V}_{2n}\subset \mathcal{V}$, then $ orall z\in B(y, rac{1}{2n})$, we have $B(x,z)\leq B(x,y)+B(y,z)< rac{1}{2n}+ rac{1}{2n}<\delta \implies x\in B(y, rac{1}{2n})\subset B(x,\delta)\subset U$, which means $\mathcal{V}$ is a countable basis of $X$. $\square$

entry.title: Topological Spaces and Continuous Functions
entry.content:
1. Topological Spaces

Definition 1.1   A topological space is an ordered pair $(X,\mathcal{T})$, where $X$ is a set and $\mathcal{T}$ is a collection of subsets of $X$, satisfying the following axioms:

  • $X$ and $\varnothing$ belong to $\mathcal{T}$.
  • Any arbitrary union of elements of $\mathcal{T}$ belongs to $\mathcal{T}$.
  • The intersection of any pair of elements of $\mathcal{T}$ belongs to $\mathcal{T}$.

The elements of $\mathcal{T}$ are called open sets and the collection $\mathcal{T}$ is called a topology on $X$

Example 1.1  

  • $2^X$ is a topology on $X$, which is called the discrete topology.
  • $\{X,\varnothing\}$ is also a topology on $X$, which is called the trivial topology.

Example 1.2  

  • $\mathcal{T}_f=\{U\subset X\colon\ X\setminus U\ ext{is finite}\}\cup\varnothing$ is a topology on $X$, which is called the cofinite topology.
  • $\mathcal{T}_c=\{U\subset X\colon\ X\setminus U\ ext{is countable}\}\cup\varnothing$ is also a topology on $X$, which is called the cocountable topology.

Definition 1.2   Suppose $\mathcal{T}$ and $\mathcal{T}’$ are two topologies on $X$. We say $\mathcal{T}$ is comparable with $\mathcal{T}’$ if either $\mathcal{T}\supset\mathcal{T}’$ or $\mathcal{T}\subset\mathcal{T}’$. If $\mathcal{T}\supset\mathcal{T}’$, we say $\mathcal{T}$ is finier than $\mathcal{T}’$. If $\mathcal{T}\subset\mathcal{T}’$, we say $\mathcal{T}$ is coarser than $\mathcal{T}’$.

2. Basis and Subbasis

Definition 2.1   A basis for a topology on $X$ is a collection $\mathcal{B}$ of subsets of $X$ satifying the following properties:

  • For each $x\in X$, there exists $B\in\mathcal{B}$ such that $x\in B$.
  • Given $B_1, B_2\in\mathcal{B}$, for each $x\in B_1\cap B_2$, there exists $B_3\in\mathcal{B}$ such that $x\in B_3\subset B_1\cap B_2$.

Proposition 2.1   If $\mathcal{B}$ is a basis for a topology on $X$, there is topology $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{B}$ generated by $\mathcal{B}$, in the sense that $U\in X$ is said to be open if for each $x\in U$, there exists $B\in\mathcal{B}$, such that $x\in B\subset U$.

Proof.  

  • It is easy to show that $X$ and $\varnothing$ are elements of $\mathcal{T}$ by the defining condition of openness.
  • For an indexed collection $\{U_\alpha\}_{\alpha\in J}$ of elements of $\mathcal{T}$, there exists an index $ eta$ for each point $x\in igcup_{\alpha\in J} U_\alpha$, such that $x\in U_ eta$. Since $U_ eta\in\mathcal{T}$, there is an element $B$ of $\mathcal{B}$ such that $x\in B\subset U_ eta\subset igcup_{\alpha\in J} U_\alpha$ which means $ igcup_{\alpha\in J} U_\alpha\in\mathcal{T}$.
  • Given $U_1, U_2\in\mathcal{T}$, for each point $x\in U_1\cap U_2$, there exist $B_1, B_2\in\mathcal{B}$ such that $x\in B_1\subset U_1$, $x\in B_2\subset U_2$. Then, there exists $B_3\in\mathcal{B}$ such that $B_3\subset B_1\cap B_2$, which means $x\in B_3\subset U_1\cap U_2$, therefore $U_1\cap U_2\in\mathcal{T}$. $\square$
$\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{B}$ is the collection of all unions of elements of $\mathcal{B}$, since for each point $x$ of an element $U$ of $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{B}$, there is an basis element $B_x$ such that $x\in B_x\subset U$, then $U= igcup_{x\in U} B_x$, and the converse is obvious. So we can also generate the topology $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{B}$ in this particular way. On the other hand, we can also obtain the basis for a given topology, as the following proposition says.

Proposition 2.2   Let $(X,\mathcal{T})$ be a topological space, $\mathcal{C}$ is a collection of open sets of $X$. If $U\in\mathcal{T}$ contains at least one element $C$ of $\mathcal{C}$ for each $x\in U$, such that $x\in C$, then $\mathcal{C}$ is a basis for $\mathcal{T}$.

Proof.  

  • Since $X$ is an open set of itself, for each point $x\in X$ there is an element $C$ of $\mathcal{C}$, such that $x\in C$.
  • Given $C_1,C_2\in\mathcal{C}$, since $C_1$ and $C_2$ are open, then $C_1\cap C_2$ is open, which means for each $x\in C_1\cap C_2$, there is an element $C_3$ of $\mathcal{C}$ such that $x\in C_3\subset C_1\cap C_2$.\
    Thus $\mathcal{C}$ is a basis for a topology. Since $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}$ is the collection of all unions of elements of $\mathcal{C}$, we have $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}\subset\mathcal{T}$, and the coverse holds guaranteed by how we define the collection $\mathcal{c}$ exactly, therefore, $\mathcal{T}_\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{T}$. $\square$

Here are some examples of topologies generated by basis.

Example 2.1  

  • Let $\mathcal{B}$ be the collection of all open interval $(a,b)$ on $\mathbb{R}$. The topology generated by $\mathcal{B}$ is called a standard topology on $\mathbb{R}$.
  • Let $\mathcal{B}’$ be the collection of all half-open interval $[a,b)$ on $\mathbb{R}$.The topology generated by $\mathcal{B}’$ is called a lower limit topology on $\mathbb{R}$. The corresponding space is denoted by $\mathbb{R}_l$.
  • Let $K=\{ rac{1}{n}\colon\ n\in\mathbb{N}\}$, $\mathcal{B}’’$ be the collection of all sets of the form $(a,b)\setminus K$ on $\mathbb{R}$. The topology generated by $\mathcal{B}’’$ is called a K-topology on $\mathbb{R}$, The corresponding space is denoted by $\mathbb{R}_K$.

Proposition 2.3   Let $\mathcal{B}$ and $\mathcal{B}’$ be bases for the topologies $\mathcal{T}$ and $\mathcal{T}’$ on $X$ respectively, then the following are equivalent:

  1. $\mathcal{T}’$ is finer than $\mathcal{T}$.
  2. For each $x\in X$ and basis element $B\in\mathcal{B}$ containing $x$, there is a basis element $B’\in\mathcal{B}’$, such that $x\in B’\subset B$.

Proof.  

  • ($\Rightarrow$).   If $\mathcal{T}’$ is finer than $\mathcal{T}$, then $\mathcal{T}\subset\mathcal{T}’$, which means for each $x\in X$, each $B\in \mathcal{B}$ containing $x$ is an element of $\mathcal{T}’$, so that there is a basis element $B’\in\mathcal{B}’$ such that $B\subset B’$.
  • ($\Leftarrow$).   Let $U\in\mathcal{T}$, then $U= igcup_{x\in U} B_x$, where $B_x\in\mathcal{B}$ is a basis element containing $x$. Since there exists a basis element $B_x’\in\mathcal{T}’$ for each $x$ such that $B_x’\subset B_x$, then $U= igcup_{x\in U} B_x’$, which means $U\in\mathcal{T}’$. $\square$

Example 2.2   The topologies of $\mathbb{R}_l$ and $\mathbb{R}_K$ are strictly finer than the standard topology on $\mathbb{R}$, but are not comparable with one another.

Definition 2.2   A subbasis $\mathcal{S}$ for a topology on $X$ is a collection of subsets of $X$ whose union equals $X$.

One can easily check that all of the finite intersections of elements of $\mathcal{S}$ form a basis for a topology $\mathcal{T}$ on $X$, then $\mathcal{T}$ can be generated by the $\mathcal{S}$ by defining $\mathcal{T}$ as a collection of all the finite intersections of $\mathcal{S}$.

Exercises

Find a homeomorphism $\varphi:\mathbb{R}^n o\mathbb{R}^n$ satisfies:

  • $\varphi=1_{\mathbb{R}^n\setminus\mathring{D^n}}$.
  • $\varphi(0)=p$, $p\in\mathring{D^n}$.

Where $D^n$ denotes the set $\{x\in\mathbb{R}^n\colon\ |x|\leq 1\}$.

Suppose that $\varphi\colon S^1 o S^1$ is a homeomorphism. Prove that there exists a homeomorphism $\psi\colon D^2 o D^2$, satisfies $\psi|_{S^1}=\varphi$.

(Hopf Link)
$$L=\{(x,y)\in\mathbb{C}^2\colon\ x^2+y^2=0, |x|^2+|y|^2=1\}$$

  1. Prove that $L\cong S^1\sqcup S^1$.
  2. Describe the image of the stereographic projection of $L$.
solution

  1. For $(x,y)\in L$，we have
    egin{gather}
    x^2+y^2 =0 \implies (y-ix)(y+ix)=0 \implies y=\pm{i}x \
    |x|^2+|y|^2 =1 \implies |x|=|y|= rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}
    \end{gather}
    Let:
    $$
    U =\{(x,ix)\in\mathbb{C}^2\colon\ |x|= rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\},\quad
    V =\{(x,-ix)\in\mathbb{C}^2\colon\ |x|= rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\}
    $$
    then $L=U\sqcup V$ and we can simply construct homeomorphisms $(x,ix)\mapsto (\sqrt{2}\operatorname{Re}(x),\sqrt{2}\operatorname{Im}(x))$, and $(x,-ix)\mapsto (\sqrt{2}\operatorname{Re}(x),\sqrt{2}\operatorname{Im}(x))$ from $U o S^1$ and $V o S^1$ respectively, so we have the conclusion $L=U\sqcup V \cong S^1\sqcup S^1$.

  2. Consider the unit 3-sphere $\{(x,y)\in\mathbb{C}^2\colon\ |x|^2+|y|^2=1\}$, the stereographic projection $P$ of the sphere from the point $(0,1)$ maps each point $(x,y)$ differs from $(0,1)$ of the sphere to the point of intersection of the real line joining $(x,y)$ and $(0,1)$ with the 3-space $\{(p,q)\in\mathbb{C}^2\colon\ \operatorname{Re}(q)=0\}$. Expicitly, when $\operatorname{Re}(y) eq 1$:
    $$
    P\colon\quad (x,y)\mapsto ( rac{\operatorname{Re}(x)}{1-\operatorname{Re}(y)}, rac{\operatorname{Im}(x)}{1-\operatorname{Re}(y)}, rac{\operatorname{Im}(y)}{1-\operatorname{Re}(y)})
    $$
    Since for each points $(x,y)\in L$, $\operatorname{Re}(y) eq 1$, we can find the image for $U$ and $V$ separately from the formula above:
    $$
    P(U)=
    egin{cases}
    u=w\
    2u^2+(v+1)^2=2
    \end{cases}\quad\quad
    P(V)=
    egin{cases}
    u=-w\
    2u^2+(v-1)^2=2
    \end{cases}
    $$
    Equivalently:
    $$
    P(U)=
    egin{cases}
    u=w\
    u^2+(v+1)^2+w^2=2
    \end{cases}\quad\quad
    P(V)=
    egin{cases}
    u=-w\
    u^2+(v-1)^2+w^2=2
    \end{cases}
    $$
    where $P(U)$ and $P(V)$ are two circles on two intersecting planes (in this case the two planes are perpendicular), and both two centers are located on the line of the intersection of the two planes. Consider the radii and the distance between the centers, the two circles are going to be linked together, in the sense that neither can be continuously shrunk to a point without pcissing through the other one (see below).

If $(X,d)$ is a metric space and $A$ is a non-empty closed set of $X$, prove that $f(x)=\inf_{a\in A}\{d(x,a)\}$ is a continuous function on $X$ and also, $f(x)=0$ if and only if $x\in A$.

Let $\mathbb{Z}$ denotes the set of integers, $U\subseteq\mathbb{Z}$ is said to be symmetrical if $n\in U$ and $-n\in U$ are equivalent for $ orall n\in \mathbb{Z}$. We define a topology $\mathcal{T}_{\mathbb{Z}}$ on $\mathbb{Z}$, that the set of $\mathbb{Z}$ is open if it is symmetrical.

  1. Prove that $\mathcal{T}_{\mathbb{Z}}$ is actually a topology.
  2. If $A=\{-1,0,1,2\}\subseteq \mathbb{Z}$, determine $\mathring{A}$, $ ar{A}$ and $A’$.
  3. Is $A$ an open set on $\mathbb{Z}$? Or is $A$ closed?

Prove that $(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\setminus\{0\})\cong (S^n imes\mathbb{R}_{>0})$, where $S^n=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\colon\ |x|=1\}$.

(Zariski Topology)   Subset $\mathbb{Z}$ of $\mathbb{C}^n$ is said to be Zariski closed if there exists polynomials $\{P_i\}_{i\in I}$ in $\mathbb{C}[x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n]$, such that $Z=\{z\in\mathbb{C}^n\colon\ P_i(z)=0, orall i\in I\}$. If the complement of $U\subseteq \mathbb{C}^n$ is Zariski closed, we say $U$ is Zariski open. Prove the following:

  1. All Zariski open sets in $\mathbb{C}^n$ forms a topology on $\mathbb{C}^n$, which is called Zariski topology.
  2. $U_f=\{x\in\mathbb{C}^n\colon f(x) eq{0}\}$ where $f\in\mathbb{C}[x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n]$, forms a topology basis of Zariski topology on $\mathbb{C}^n$.
  3. Suppose that $f_1,f_2,\dots,f_m$ are polynomials of $\mathbb{C}[x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n]$. Prove the map:
    $$(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)\mapsto(f_1(x),f_2(x),\dots,f_m(x))$$
    is continuous if we consider the Zariski topology on both $\mathbb{C}^n$ and $\mathbb{C}^m$.

entry.title: Topology
entry.content:
2. Separation Axioms

2.1. Hausdorff Spaces

Definition.     A topological space $X$ is called a Hausdorff space if for each pair $x_1,x_2$ of distinct points of $X$, there exist neighborhoods $U_1$, $U_2$ of $x_1$ and $x_2$ respectively, that are disjoint.

Proposition 2.1.1.    $X$ is a Hausdorff space if for each poin $p$ of $X$, there exists a continuous function $f\colon X\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $f^{-1}(0)={p}$.

Proof.    For each pair $p$, $q$ of distint points of $X$, if there exists a continuous function $f\colon X\to\mathbb{R}$ such that $f^{-1}(0)={p}$, we have $f(p)=0$ and $f(q)=c\neq 0$. Let $\delta=\frac{|c|}{2}>0$, $U=(-\delta,\delta)$, and $V=(c-\delta,c+\delta)$, then $f^{-1}(U)$, $f^{-1}(V)$ are neighborhoods of $p$ and $q$ respectively, and $f^{-1}(U)\cap f^{-1}(V)=\varnothing$. Therefore, $X$ is a Hausdorff space. $\square$

Proposition 2.1.2.    $X$ is a Hausdorff space if and only if the image of the diagonal map $\Delta(X)={(x,x)\colon x\in X}$ is closed in $X\times X$.

Proof.    Since $X$ is a Hausdorff space, for each distinct points $x,y$ of $X$, there exists neighborhoods $U$, $V$ of $x$ and $y$ respectively, and $U\cap V=\varnothing$, then $(U\times V)\cap \Delta(X)=\varnothing$ where $(U\times V)$ is a neighborhood of $(x,y)\in X\times X$, and that means $(\Delta(X))^C$ is open, therefore $\Delta(X)$ is closed. Conversely, if $\Delta(X)$ is closed in $X\times X$, we have $(\Delta(X))^C$ is open, then each $(x,y)\in (\Delta(X))^C$ has a neighborhood with form $U\times V$ where $U$ and $V$ are open in $X$, that is disjoint with $\Delta(X)$, then $U$ and $V$ are neighborhoods of $x$ and $y$ in $X$ respectively, that are disjoint. Therefore, $X$ is a Hausdorff space. $\square$
